soilnotes: Paralleling the northern perimeter of the lake is a late Paleozoic and early Mesozoic serpentine block. An alluvial delta forms a large portion of Finca Los Murcielagos. In addition to terrestrial alluviums, Simmons, Tarano and Pinto (1959) have classified two soil series which are present at lower elevations along the north lake shoreline. The Sebach series, dark-brown clays, and the Guaipol series, red-brown clays, are developed wholly or in part on serpentine material. Most of the upland soils at Finca Los Murcielagos are Oxisols, with hydromorphic forms, and Inceptisols. Black-to-yellowish-brown clays derived from limestone, serpentine and other transported materials. Other soils are sand and gravel.

soilnotes: The topography consists of gently rolling hills which rise up to 50 m above the mean river level. The hill forests are never flooded and have soils consisting of a sandy horizon (from a few centimetres to 2 m in depth) over- lying a thick horizon composed of kaolinite clay and lateritic concretions. These soils are classified as Oxisols (United States 7th approximation) or Ferralsols (FAO classification). Both horizons are acid and highly weathered, and have low cation exchange capacity and high iron and aluminum content (Jordan 1982). Above the mineral soil is a mat of humus and roots which plays an important role in nutrient cycling (Jordan and Herrera 1981).

soilnotes: Soils in the experimental watersheds of the HBEF are generally Spodosols (Soil Survey Staff 1975) of sandy loam texture with pH <4.5. They are characterized by  a thick, highly organic forest floor and a spodic horizon in which amorphous sesquioxides and organic matter  have accumulated. Cobbles and boulders abound in the profile. Iron and organic matter are mobilized in the forest floor and the E horizon by soil water, and subsequently are deposited in the spodic horizon

sites.sitename: Hubbard Brook W5- scarified soil disturbance

sites.sitename: Intensive Management Practices Assessment Center loblolly pine plantation (control)
soilnotes: Sandy, siliceous, hyperthermic Ultic Alaquods. In a typical profile, the spodic horizon occurs at 20-50 cm and an argillic hrizon at 90-120 cm. The soil nutrient reserves are inherently low, as the A horizon is comprised predominantly of quartz sand that has low organic matter content and cation exchange capcity (<5 cmolckg-1).

geography.notes: coordinates are for Darwin.  four study sites were used, all located within a 65 km radius of Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia. Sites were located at (1) Howard Springs (12 degrees 28 seconds S, 131deg 08 sec E), (2) Humpty Doo (12deg 36secS, 131deg 10secE), (3) the Territory Wildlife Park (12deg 42secS, 131deg 0 sec E) and (4) a fourth site at Gunn Point (12deg 14sec S, 131deg 05secE).
climate.notes: The climate of the region is wet-dry tropical and rainfall is distinctly seasonal, with a wet season occurring from November to April (Cook and Heerdegen 2001). During this period, greater than 90% of the 1,700 mm annual rainfall occurs. The dry season occurs from May to October with little or no rainfall. Temperatures remain high throughout the year with mean daily maximum temperatures at the Darwin Airport (35 km from the field site) ranging from 30.4 C (July) to 33.1 C (October and November). Maximum and minimum temperatures have a range of 7 C (wet season) to 11 C (dry season) (McDonald and McAlpine 1991).
soilnotes: well drained lateritic red and yellow earth soils, which tend to have A horizons of well drained, highly weathered sands (clay content typically <5%, Calder and Day 1982) of low nutrient status, with a massive and earthy structure. Transition at 15_30 cm to a sandy loam B horizon is gradational and can extend up to 1_2 m, where ferricrete boulders occur in a matrix of mottled, heavy clays forming a duricrust of low permeability and variable depth (Calder and Day 1982). Prominent macropores, often containing tree roots, are found in this layer. Rounded ferricrete gravels can occur on the sandy soil surface and throughout the profile up to 20% by volume. These soils are generally acidic (pH approximately 5.5, Calder and Day 1982) and low in available N and P (total N, 0.1% Schmidt et al. 1998). Dry bulk densities of these soils range from approximately 1.4 kg m 3 at the surface to 1.7 kg m 3 at depth (2 m).
